> >For double:
> >
> >	network.setInputSignal(0, state[0] / trackLength);
> >	network.setInputSignal(1, state[1] / 2.0);
> >	network.setInputSignal(2, state[2] / 0.52);
> >	network.setInputSignal(3, state[3] / 2.0);
> >	network.setInputSignal(4, state[4] / 0.52);
> >	network.setInputSignal(5, state[5] / 2.0);
> >
> >For double it seems like you don't actually get values scaled
> >between 0 and 1 or -1 and 1.
> >  
> >
> It looks liek they're scaled to -1 to 1 to me.

I don't think so.  States 2 and 4 are in radians, which means they're
between -PI and PI (unless I'm reading the code wrong).  So dividing
by 0.52 yields approximately -6 ... 6.  And state 0 ranges from
-trackLength/2 to trackLength/2, so it's scaled to -0.5 ... 0.5.  None
of this keeps the net from solving the problem, but they seem odd choices.

Another difference I noticed between Markovian and non-Markovian
double pole balancing is that one had a bias of 1.0, the other 0.5. 
Any reason for that?

Thanks,
Philip
